reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s move (in the unbounded-linear section) from “value-efficiency is plausibly fat-tailed” to “mostly-great futures are a narrow target by default.” That move supports one important strand of the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ case, but the position also leans heavily on other routes to fussiness (multiplicative fragility across dimensions; bounded-view arguments about bads; etc.), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive. Substantively, the critique is fairly strong: fat-tailed payoff distributions alone don’t determine how much probability mass lies near the top without assumptions about the induced distribution over outcomes from social/AI optimization dynamics, and the paper largely gestures rather than models this. However, it’s not a full refutation: the paper’s claim is framed around “no serious coordinated de dicto optimization,” and it offers additional reasons (astronomical design space; plausibly small fraction of near-max uses) that could still make the target narrow even with some default selection pressures. Correctness is high: the need for a bridge from tail-shape to typical-outcome quality is a valid methodological point, though the suggestion that fat tails typically mean “many near-winners” is not guaranteed in general (heavy tails can still leave very little mass near the extreme). The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Critique lacks model of search dynamics to bridge fat tails to narrow eutopia
